page.title: 04FARMING: DAIRYING
page.content: In June 1985, a 5 year struggle ended to preserve a herd of 258 pedigree {Friesian dairy cattle,}with the respected 'Deerhurst' prefix, started at Wightfield Manor in 1919 by Alfred Ludlow-Hewitt. The top bid was 600 guineas (Â£630) for 'Deerhurst Baby'. There are two major reasons for the failure of this herd. Firstly the{ {E.E.C.,}to which Britain has belonged since 1972, has sought to cut excessive milk production by the imposition of quotas which have hit British dairy farmers particularly harshly. Consequently to change the method of farming requires the abandoning of capital equipment and purchase of new machinary since this is the foundation of agricultural efficiency. Record rates of interest on borrowed capital has forced the owners to sell their farm & herd.
